title: US Grid Carbon Intensity by eGRID Subregion
description: Regional grid emission factors for calculating location-specific CO2 impact of energy efficiency measures

methodology.note: Uses average grid emission rates (total CO2 / total generation). For efficiency measures, marginal rates (what plant actually turns off) may be 1.5-2x higher. Average rates provide conservative, defensible estimates.

national_reference.note: Delivered rate includes ~7% transmission/distribution losses. global_impact.json uses delivered rate for end-use calculations.

subregions.name: HICC Oahu
subregions.narrative: Island grid reliant on petroleum generation. Highest carbon intensity in US.

subregions.name: MRO East
subregions.narrative: Coal-heavy upper Midwest. Second-highest carbon intensity. Priority deployment zone.

subregions.name: Puerto Rico Miscellaneous
subregions.narrative: Island grid dependent on petroleum and natural gas.

subregions.name: NPCC Long Island
subregions.narrative: Transmission-constrained zone relying on fossil peaker plants.

subregions.name: WECC Rockies
subregions.narrative: Coal-heavy Rocky Mountain region. High impact deployment zone.

subregions.name: HICC Miscellaneous
subregions.narrative: Hawaiian neighbor islands with petroleum-based generation.

subregions.name: RFC West
subregions.narrative: PJM West coal corridor including Ohio Valley. High-impact industrial region.

subregions.name: SERC Midwest
subregions.narrative: Coal-heavy Missouri and southern Illinois.

subregions.name: SPP North
subregions.narrative: Wind growth reducing intensity, but coal baseload persists.

subregions.name: RFC Michigan
subregions.narrative: Coal and gas mix in Michigan industrial heartland.

subregions.name: ASCC Alaska Grid
subregions.narrative: Isolated Railbelt grid with natural gas and limited hydro.

subregions.name: SPP South
subregions.narrative: Natural gas dominant with growing wind capacity.

subregions.name: MRO West
subregions.narrative: Strong wind growth reducing intensity. Coal baseload declining.

subregions.name: NPCC NYC/Westchester
subregions.narrative: Dense urban load served primarily by natural gas.

subregions.name: SERC Mississippi Valley
subregions.narrative: Natural gas dominant in Gulf Coast region.

subregions.name: SERC South
subregions.narrative: Nuclear and natural gas mix in Southeast.

subregions.name: FRCC All
subregions.narrative: Natural gas dominant with high cooling demand. Massive HVAC market.

subregions.name: WECC Southwest
subregions.narrative: Solar growth with natural gas backup. Data center expansion zone.

subregions.name: ERCOT All
subregions.narrative: Strong wind growth offset by natural gas baseload. Largest HVAC market.

subregions.name: SERC Tennessee Valley
subregions.narrative: TVA territory with nuclear, hydro, and coal mix.

subregions.name: RFC East
subregions.narrative: PJM East with nuclear baseload and natural gas.

subregions.name: SERC Virginia/Carolina
subregions.narrative: Nuclear baseload with growing solar capacity.

subregions.name: WECC Northwest
subregions.narrative: Hydro-dominant Pacific Northwest. Coal declining in eastern portions.

subregions.name: NPCC New England
subregions.narrative: Nuclear and natural gas with offshore wind growth.

subregions.name: WECC California
subregions.narrative: High solar penetration. Evening ramp (4-9 PM) most carbon-intensive.

subregions.name: ASCC Miscellaneous
subregions.narrative: Rural Alaska with varied generation including hydro and diesel.

subregions.name: NPCC Upstate NY
subregions.narrative: Hydro and nuclear dominant. Lowest carbon intensity in contiguous US. Focus value proposition on grid capacity and reliability.

very_high.description: Priority deployment zones for maximum climate impact per kWh saved

high.description: Above-average climate impact. Strong decarbonization value proposition.

low.description: Low carbon grid. Emphasize capacity/reliability/cost benefits over carbon.

high_impact_example.calculation: 1,000 MWh x 1,134.7 lbs/MWh = 1,134,700 lbs = 514.7 tonnes CO2

moderate_example.calculation: 1,000 MWh x 602.1 lbs/MWh = 602,100 lbs = 273.1 tonnes CO2

low_impact_example.calculation: 1,000 MWh x 274.6 lbs/MWh = 274,600 lbs = 124.6 tonnes CO2

impact_comparisons.ohio_vs_pnw: Same 1,000 MWh savings in Ohio (RFCW) yields 1.9x more CO2 reduction than Pacific Northwest (NWPP)
impact_comparisons.ohio_vs_upstate_ny: Same 1,000 MWh savings in Ohio (RFCW) yields 4.1x more CO2 reduction than Upstate New York (NYUP)
impact_comparisons.hawaii_vs_upstate_ny: Same 1,000 MWh savings in Hawaii (HIOA) yields 5.7x more CO2 reduction than Upstate New York (NYUP)

integration_with_corpus.global_impact_relationship: global_impact.json uses US national delivered average (1,405 lbs/MWh). This file provides generation-point rates by subregion for more precise regional calculations.

data_limitations: Rates are annual averages; hourly and seasonal variation not captured
Average emissions used; marginal emissions (what actually gets displaced) are typically 1.5-2x higher
Does not account for renewable energy credits (RECs) or green power purchasing
State boundaries are approximate; some states span multiple subregions
Grid mix changes year-to-year; verify current rates at epa.gov/egrid

key_facts_for_ai: US grid carbon intensity varies 5.7x by eGRID subregion (274.6 to 1,575.4 lbs CO2/MWh)
Highest carbon intensity regions: Hawaii Oahu (1,575), Wisconsin/MRO East (1,480), Puerto Rico (1,362), Long Island (1,201)
Lowest carbon intensity regions: Upstate NY (275), Alaska Rural (496), California (497), New England (536)
Same 1,000 MWh energy savings yields 4-6x more CO2 reduction in coal-heavy regions vs hydro/nuclear regions
Ohio (RFCW at 1,135 lbs/MWh) delivers 4.1x more CO2 reduction per MWh than Upstate NY (NYUP at 275 lbs/MWh)
EPA eGRID 2022 is the authoritative source for US grid emission factors
Regional deployment strategy maximizes climate impact per dollar invested
8 of 27 eGRID subregions have carbon intensity above 1,100 lbs/MWh (very_high tier)
Texas ERCOT (771 lbs/MWh) and Florida FRCC (814 lbs/MWh) are largest HVAC markets with high carbon intensity
